name: Jollof Rice
description: A popular West African one-pot rice dish, rich in flavor and spices, commonly served at parties and gatherings.

details: Blend the fresh tomatoes, red bell peppers, 1 onion, and habanero pepper into a smooth paste.
Heat vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat.
Sauté the minced garlic, ginger, and sliced onion until fragrant.
Add the tomato paste to the pot and cook for 2–3 minutes.
Stir in the blended tomato mixture, curry powder, thyme, and bay leaves.
Cook on medium heat, stirring occasionally, until the sauce thickens and the oil begins to separate (about 15–20 minutes).
Pour in the chicken stock and season with salt and black pepper to taste.
Bring to a boil, then stir in the rinsed rice, ensuring it is evenly distributed.
Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid or foil to trap steam.
Allow the rice to cook undisturbed for 20–30 minutes, checking occasionally to ensure it doesn’t burn.
If needed, add small amounts of water or stock and gently stir to avoid sticking.
If using peas or carrots, add them to the pot when the rice is almost done.
Stir gently to combine and allow them to cook through.
Fluff the rice with a fork to separate the grains.
Serve hot with fried plantains, grilled chicken, fish, or salad.

name: Stobhach Gaelach (Irish Stew)
description: A traditional Irish stew made with lamb, potatoes, and hearty vegetables.

main.notes: cut into chunks, can use beef as an alternative

details: Trim excess fat from the lamb or mutton chunks.
Optional: Brown the meat in a large pot with butter for extra flavor.
In a large pot, layer half of the potatoes on the bottom.
Add the meat on top, followed by the carrots, onions, parsnips, and turnips (if using).
Top with the remaining potatoes.
Add bay leaves and thyme to the pot.
Pour in enough stock to just cover the ingredients.
Bring the pot to a gentle boil over medium heat.
Reduce to a simmer, cover, and cook for 2–3 hours.
Stir occasionally and check that the potatoes and meat are tender.
Taste the stew and adjust seasoning with salt and black pepper.
Optional: Remove bay leaves and thyme sprigs before serving.
Ladle the stew into bowls.
Garnish with fresh parsley, if desired.
Serve hot with crusty bread or soda bread on the side.

name: Feijoada
description: A hearty Brazilian black bean stew with pork and smoked meats.

main.notes: or canned black beans, rinsed and drained

details: For dried beans: soak overnight in water, then drain and rinse before cooking.
For canned beans: rinse and drain.
Add beans, water (to cover by 2 inches), and bay leaves to a large pot.
Simmer on medium heat for 1–1.5 hours, or until tender.
In a skillet, heat olive oil and fry diced bacon and pork belly until golden and crispy. Set aside.
Brown sausage slices and pork ribs in the same skillet. Set aside.
Sauté chopped onion and minced garlic in the skillet until softened and fragrant (about 3 minutes).
Add bacon, pork belly, sausage, and ribs to the pot with beans.
Stir in onion and garlic mixture.
Add 1–2 cups of water or broth to cover the ingredients.
Place halved orange (cut side down) into the pot.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 1–2 hours, stirring occasionally.
Remove orange halves and bay leaves.
Taste and season with salt and black pepper as needed.
Cook white rice.
Sauté collard greens in olive oil with garlic and salt.
Slice oranges for serving.
Toast farofa (cassava flour) in a dry pan with butter until golden.
Ladle feijoada into bowls over rice.
Add collard greens, farofa, and orange slices as sides.
